repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: currently don't have normal commands docstring

Solution: move `nv_cmds` structs from normal.c to normal_cmds.lua and add desc


relate #19918 https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/8029#issuecomment-1175146743

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -102,6 +102,11 @@ static int VIsual_mode_orig = NUL;              // saved Visual mode
 # include "normal.c.generated.h"
 #endif
 
+// Declare nv_cmds[].
+#ifdef INCLUDE_GENERATED_DECLARATIONS
+# include "normal_cmds_defs.generated.h"

@@ -0,0 +1,1158 @@
+local bit = require('bit')
+
+-- Description the NV_ flag values for cmd_flags

comment_data.body: I don't think this block should be in a generated file.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,48 @@
+local autodir = arg[1]
+
+local deffname = autodir .. '/normal_cmds.generated.h'
+local defsfile = io.open(deffname, 'w')
+
+defsfile:write [[
+#include "nvim/normal_defs.h"
+
+/// Function to be called for a Normal or Visual mode command.
+/// The argument is a cmdarg_T.
+typedef void (*nv_func_T)(cmdarg_T *cap);
+
+// Generally speaking, every Normal mode command should either clear any
+// pending operator (with *clearop*()), or set the motion type variable
+// oap->motion_type.
+//
+// When a cursor motion command is made, it is marked as being a character or
+// line oriented motion.  Then, if an operator is in effect, the operation
+// becomes character or line oriented accordingly.

comment_data.body: emm before i am think also generate flag from script..so i leave this comment ..but they only used in normal.c no need in header file ..so forget delete.

+// line oriented motion.  Then, if an operator is in effect, the operation

comment_data.body: Could use `vim.spairs()` here, then the structure could be a map instead of a list. That may be helpful for exposing `src/nvim/normal_cmds.lua` as a runtime file (in the future).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,40 @@
+local autodir = arg[1]
+
+local deffname = autodir .. '/normal_cmds.generated.h'
+local defsfile = io.open(deffname, 'w')
+
+defsfile:write [[
+#include "nvim/normal_defs.h"
+
+/// Function to be called for a Normal or Visual mode command.
+/// The argument is a cmdarg_T.
+typedef void (*nv_func_T)(cmdarg_T *cap);
+
+/// This table contains one entry for every Normal or Visual mode command.
+/// The order doesn't matter, init_normal_cmds() will create a sorted index.
+/// It is faster when all keys from zero to '~' are present.
+static const struct nv_cmd {
+  int cmd_char;                 ///< (first) command character
+  nv_func_T cmd_func;           ///< function for this command
+  uint16_t cmd_flags;           ///< NV_ flags
+  int16_t cmd_arg;              ///< value for ca.arg
+} nv_cmds[] = {
+]]
+
+local normal = require('normal_cmds')
+for i, item in ipairs(normal.nv_cmds) do

comment_data.body: This maps to an internal C macro, right? A major goal of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/19918 is to allow us to expose these Lua data files in the runtime, for use by plugins/users. So exposing a new way to represent keycodes isn't a good idea. Can we use the standard keycode convention here? Or a literal char?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,1157 @@

+

comment_data.body: Can we now remove the C definitions of these (and the others...) flags?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,1157 @@

+local NONE = 0

comment_data.body:
Using `ex_cmds.lua` as a reference, and thinking about how this data will be used, I don't see a reason why we would need the `cmd_` prefix on the fields.

These should also be documented at the top of this file. A `@class` may be helpful: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/f6a3fdd6848d67dc54cebb6c297f8ebdc109c3a3/src/nvim/eval.lua#L5

```suggestion
    char = 'Ctrl_B',
    func = 'nv_page',
    flags = STS,
    arg = BACKWARD,
```

+    cmd_arg = BACKWARD,

title: refactor(normal.c): move nv_cmds to normal.lua
